title: Application of causal inference to everyday life
body:
I've seen causal inference hailed as a topic that has important implications and broad applications, and I've seen many people getting excited about it. Examples:

* Andrew Critch ([1](http://acritch.com/media/mphd/mphd-2012-02-08-causal-diagrams.pdf), [2](http://acritch.com/media/mphd/causal-graphs-and-thinking-hats.pdf), [3](http://www.acritch.com/media/math/critch-causality-talk-slides.pdf), [4](http://www.acritch.com/media/math/critch-slides-causality-and-algebraic-geometry.pdf))
* https://globalprioritiesinstitute.org/gpi-workshop-on-causal-inference-and-extrapolation/
* Eliezer Yudkowsky https://www.greaterwrong.com/posts/hzuSDMx7pd2uxFc5w/causal-diagrams-and-causal-models (probably more [here](https://www.greaterwrong.com/search?q=eliezer+yudkowsky+pearl))
* Peter McCluskey: http://bayesianinvestor.com/books.html
* Michael Nielsen ([1](http://www.michaelnielsen.org/ddi/if-correlation-doesnt-imply-causation-then-what-does/), [2](http://www.michaelnielsen.org/ddi/guest-post-judea-pearl-on-correlation-causation-and-the-psychology-of-simpsons-paradox/))
* gwern: https://www.gwern.net/Causality
* Yan Zhang/Boris Alexeev: https://concretenonsense.wordpress.com/2013/02/16/defense-against-the-dark-arts-the-reverse-regression-effect/
* Maybe more here: https://www.facebook.com/search/str/pearl+causality/keywords_blended_posts?filters_rp_author=stories-feed-friends

However, even after spending some time reading and thinking about this, I feel like I have little idea how to go about applying this to my everyday life. (I can understand why it is intellectually interesting, and I think if I spent a lot more time thinking about this, I could probably come up with good ways to apply it.)

I'm not exactly sure what sort of output I am imagining, but something like a tutorial on how to go about applying ideas from causal inference to everyday life would be interesting to me. Some things this tutorial could include:

* How to spot Simpson's paradox and resolve it (this might be better for [Hunting for Simpson's paradox](https://machinelearning.subwiki.org/wiki/Hunting_for_Simpson%27s_paradox))
* How to draw a causal graph for a situation (again, this might be better as a standalone piece at e.g. [Creation of causal graphs](https://machinelearning.subwiki.org/wiki/Creation_of_causal_graphs))
* How to figure out which variables you need to adjust for (e.g. when evaluating an empirical study)
* A more advanced/sophisticated version of Andrew Critch's [worksheet](http://acritch.com/media/mphd/causal-graphs-and-thinking-hats.pdf)

title: Timeline of effective altruism
body: I have a small draft at https://timelines.issarice.com/wiki/Timeline_of_effective_altruism

title: Reference class tennis
body:
it is mentioned a bit in https://wiki.lesswrong.com/wiki/Outside_view and wikipedia has https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reference_class_forecasting#Reference_class_tennis but this should be expanded much more

I've seen this mentioned in many places (often by Eliezer Yudkowsky), but I think there hasn't been enough systematization about e.g. when it's ok vs when to avoid, how it happens.

some recent revival of the Modesty Debate also talks about this

title: San Francisco Bay Area as a rationalist and effective altruist hub
body: I started on this at https://wiki.lesswrong.com/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay_Area_as_a_rationalist_and_effective_altruist_hub (it's mostly a link-dump)

title: Timeline of cause areas and crucial considerations
body:
When did the importance of the following cause areas (and others) become known? animal welfare, women's rights, environmentalism, AI safety. I'm interested in this from the perspective of intellectual ideas behind the causes rather than when the cause areas became movements or mainstream. (The latter would be important from a movement-building perspective, but I am interested in this from a "Cause X" perspective.)

I'm curious about whether there is some pattern in how we discover more causes, and when we can expect new causes to be discovered. We can ask the same thing with "crucial considerations" instead of causes. When were various "crucial considerations" like astronomical waste, the great filter, orthogonality thesis, and so forth discovered? When can we expect the next "crucial consideration" to be discovered?

It might be worth looking at Jeremy Bentham, who endorsed many of these ideas before they were widely accepted. See also Yew-Kwang Ng.

title: List of information aggregation mechanisms and their properties
body: Is there some name other than "information aggregation mechanism"?

title: Updatelessness
body:
I would like to see a page or post (or table) exploring all the different meanings of updatelessness in decision theory.

My draft for #30 discusses some of this, but at the moment I don't understand enough decision theory (and some of its prerequisites, like logical induction) to do a good job of this.

* Eells

title: Splitting donations vs donating to a single place
body:
There has been a lot of discussions about this but I don't know of any central place that consolidates all the arguments and what the current consensus view is.

I'm not sure what the best output format is.

title: Offline Facebook Messenger chat search
body:
Messenger's own search feature is pretty bad (can't search far back into history, matches common words I don't want to match, can't use regular expressions, etc.). I think it wouldn't be hard to write a script that uses the Facebook data export to search for messages.

I tried looking for something like this a while back but couldn't find anything.

title: Applicability of FDT/UDT/TDT to everyday life
body: See https://github.com/riceissa/issarice.com/blob/master/external/wiki.lesswrong.com/Application_of_functional_updateless_timeless_decision_theory_to_everyday_life.mediawiki for a draft

title: Belief polarization
body:
It looks like I got briefly interested in this two years ago. Now I don't remember what exactly I had in mind, but I have a folder on my computer with the following:

* Bullock. "Bayesian Updating of Political Beliefs: Normative and Descriptive Properties".
* Fryer, Harms, and Jackson. "Updating Beliefs when Evidence is Open to Interpretation: Implications for Bias and Polarization". May 2016.
* Zimper and Ludwig. "On attitude polarization under Bayesian learning with non-additive beliefs". July 2008.
* Zimper and Ludwig. "On attitude polarization under Bayesian learning with non-additive beliefs". February, 2009.
* Benoit and Dubra. "A Theory of Rational Attitude Polarization". March 2015.
* A quote from Jaynes, _Probability Theory: the logic of science_, under the section "Mental activity" (p. xxv).
* Jaynes, "Queer uses for probability theory" (chapter 5).
* Jern, Chang, and Kemp. "Bayesian Belief Polarization".
* Jern, Chang, and Kemp. "Belief Polarization Is Not Always Irrational". 2014.
* Baliga, Hanany, and Klibanoff. "Polarization and Ambiguity".

There is a Wikipedia page at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Group_polarization but I think it doesn't cover the Bayesian justification, which might be what bugged me.

See also https://www.greaterwrong.com/posts/2jfSi6HhTqWDKLQwm/lesswrong-help-desk-free-paper-downloads-and-more/comment/JnuSsezfoh8n6fHeh

title: Premise selection
body: I'm searching both "premise selection" and "premiss selection" but can't find a page that explains this (it's mentioned in a bunch of papers).

title: Reasoning behind "Basic Security Guide"
body:
I've seen the ["Basic Security Guide"](https://techsolidarity.org/resources/basic_security.htm) published by Tech Solidary recommended. There are also a few more pages listed in the [resources](https://techsolidarity.org/resources.html) page. While some of the recommendations (like "Use a long passphrase to lock your devices") sound obvious, others (like "Use Chrome as your browser") are mysterious to me. I would like to see more of the reasoning behind each recommendation. I tried looking a bit but was unable to find discussions about the reasoning.

I'm pretty uncertain about the effort tag here. It might turn out to be really easy if there is existing discussion, but on the other hand if I have to re-derive everything by going back to first principles, that will take a lot of time.

title: Linear algebra proof tricks
body:
I've noticed that a lot of the exercises in _Linear Algebra Done Right_ are quite repetitive in how you should solve them. Besides the basic proof tricks, I feel like a lot of the problems are just a search through some equivalent properties and guessing which one might be useful. Some more concrete examples:

- When dealing with a finite-dimensional vector space, you often want to go back to the definition by defining an explicit basis.
- When dealing with invertible operators, you can use one of the equivalent properties (injective, surjective, etc.).
- Getting some linearly independent vectors, and then extending it to a basis somehow.

I think it would be nice to list some of these tricks in detail and give examples.

The only thing I've seen that's somewhat like this is ["Proving statements in linear algebra"](http://www.math.columbia.edu/~thaddeus/linear/proof.pdf) but it's too short. I think the Tricki has at least one linear algebra trick but I find it hard to navigate.

title: Systematically recording decision problems
body:
One question I have about decision theory is how people are even coming up with the different decision problems. Some of them only differ in the payoff matrix. But there are other differences like:

- the characters in play (Omega, copies of yourself, other players)
- randomness (e.g. coin flip in the death in Damascus problem)
- the information you get to see (e.g. normal Newcomb vs clear box Newcomb)

I think one way to make progress on understanding this is to try to systematically record existing decision problems, in a machine-readable way (or almost-machine-readable way, like an HTML table). That way, you can start "enumerating" decision problems starting at the simplest, and be able to "locate" the existing problems at some number in your enumeration (I making an analogy with enumeration proofs in logic, but this is probably not useful). Along the way, you will discover other decision problems.

Another way to analogize this is with theorem proving in math. I am thinking especially of ["A Fully Automatic Theorem Prover with Human-Style Output"](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10817-016-9377-1) by Ganesalingam and Gowers, and how Gowers likes to say that a lot of undergraduate math proofs can be done on autopilot. Is there some systematic way to understand how people are coming up with decision problems, such that the process can be automated? Is there a way to tell which decision problems are interesting?

Actually, since I am a decision theory noob, it is quite possible someone has already done something like this, so a first step would be to look for existing work.

title: Adjustment problem
body: Similar to #37.

title: Reverse regression
body: See the epilogue of Judea Pearl's _Causality_. I can't find a good wiki-like reference page for this idea. Does one exist?

title: Fundamental obstructions
body:
see:

- https://agentfoundations.org/item?id=1129

- https://ai-alignment.com/directions-and-desiderata-for-ai-control-b60fca0da8f4

I haven't done enough enough theoretical computer science or math to understand this intuition, but it would be nice to have more examples of these "fundamental obstructions".

I'm not sure about the venue; maybe LW or LW Wiki would be fine.

title: Fix spaces in Internet Archive citations
body:
e.g. https://web.archive.org/web/20090117180414/http://www.fhi.ox.ac.uk:80/Papers/July%20Bimonthly%20Progress%20Report.pdf

the `url` parameter comes with regular spaces rather than escaped with `%20`.

check archive.is as well

title: Make it easier for people to ask me questions
body:
It seems like a lot of tumblr people get a lot of questions despite being not very famous and only pseudonymous. I wonder if I am somehow discouraging people from asking me more questions.

There is already facebook/quora/email, but it might be worth setting up some sort of dedicated form or having a spot on e.g. the LW AMA thread.

title: AI safety funding sources
body:
see https://www.greaterwrong.com/posts/DbPJGNS79qQfZcDm7/funding-for-ai-alignment-research#comment-BXJerxNdsnobShciR

there is now also https://www.greaterwrong.com/posts/SqcPWvvJJwwgZb6aH/prize-for-probable-problems

columns could be title, source, date range, amount range, eligibility, open-endedness/topic

title: Population ethics tool
body: See https://causeprioritization.org/Population_ethics_tool_idea

title: Better design for online documents
body: I'm not satisfied with any website design that exists today. My [own website](https://issarice.com) is my attempt so far to design a good simple site, but there are still parts I don't like, e.g. how it handles large tables. [Distill](https://distill.pub/guide/) looks good but I don't want to write in an idiosyncratic HTML format. I think Medium and LessWrong 2.0 (and [GreaterWrong](https://www.greaterwrong.com/)) are gesturing toward something similar to what I want, but I don't like either of them too much. For me, the ideal output would be a Pandoc template with a CSS stylesheet so that I could write in Pandoc Markdown.

title: TDT vs UDT vs FDT
body: A page describing how these decision theories are related. I understand that TDT is now deprecated and UDT is an example of FDT, but what exactly did TDT get wrong that is no longer part of FDT? How does UDT differ from other FDTs?

title: Psycho-conservatism
body:
A wiki page about the topic, covering proponents, major beliefs, books, blogs, groups within the broader [rationality community](https://issarice.com/rationality-community) that discuss it, etc.

The term comes from [this blog post](https://srconstantin.wordpress.com/2017/11/02/psycho-conservatism-what-it-is-when-to-doubt-it/).

title: Magical reality fluid
body: A page about what it is and any progress made on understanding it. Some links: [1](https://www.facebook.com/alyssamvance/posts/10205442165803261), [2](https://www.google.com/search?q=%22magical%20reality%20fluid%22), [3](http://lesswrong.com/lw/ua/the_level_above_mine/8bww).

title: Mapping out EA/impact-focused projects
body: Two projects that were released in 2017 are [EA Work Club](http://www.eawork.club/) (announced [December 2017](http://effective-altruism.com/ea/1i7/introducing_ea_work_club_highimpact_jobs_and_side/)) and the [Diaspora Project Map](https://namespace.obormot.net/Main/DiasporaProjectMap) (announced [December 2017](https://www.lesserwrong.com/posts/fDhy3PXvJ6sjBJQB8/show-lw-diaspora-project-map-and-preregistration-database)). However, I think both of these suffer from the "make it and they will come" mindset. While the tools look decent, without data, I think people are unwilling to contribute their own data. So the idea would be to go out and find more projects and add them to one of these or add them to some other list of projects (I think .impact also had a hackpad containing a bunch of projects at one point).

title: Better conversion from MediaWiki to Markdown
body:
I think Pandoc is the best converter at the moment, but it doesn't handle templates, which are used a lot in MediaWiki documents. Maybe writing a Pandoc filter to handle templates can get decent output. Or maybe some method involving going from MediaWiki to some intermediate format, then to Markdown would work.

I made some progress on this at https://github.com/riceissa/pandocfilters-examples/blob/master/mediawiki_refs.lua but Pandoc does not parse duplicate ref tags (the `name` attribute for the tag) so you get a lot of blank footnotes.

title: DeWitt clause
body: A page explaining DeWitt clauses, some examples, its history, etc. There is a tiny amount of info on [David DeWitt's page](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_DeWitt).

title: Timeline of machine learning pedagogy
body:
This timeline wouldn't cover cutting-edge research, but rather learning resources dedicated to machine learning. Some things to cover: various subreddits, Ng's ML courses, Distill, various textbooks.

See also my https://machinelearning.subwiki.org/wiki/Comparison_of_machine_learning_textbooks

title: Research Japanese input method engines
body: This might just be my ignorance, but in my experience there is no really good free software Japanese IME. All of the ones I have tried work reasonably well but a lot of their kanji suggestions are way off or not present in their dictionaries. Even mozc, developed by Google, seems to be some inferior free software version of the actual IME they use for Google's keyboard. Is there really nothing really good out there? Could one of the existing engines be fairly easily brought to a higher quality by assembling better dictionaries?

title: Wikipedia pages for AGI projects
body: Specifically those AGI projects listed in [Seth Baum's paper](https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3070741). Some of these projects already have Wikipedia pages but many do not. Writing each page should take less than a day of work, so each page would be a `low_effort` in terms of effort, but since I am too lazy to list each page here, I'll record the effort as a `high_effort`.

title: Guide on choosing data storage formats
body: I have especially small-to-medium scales in mind. When should one use a CSV/TSV file? When should one store data as a SQL file or dump? There's a lot of intuition one would need to transmit.

title: Amazon Lightsail
body: Similar pages exist for e.g. [AWS Lambda](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AWS_Lambda).

title: Hostile wife phenomenon
body: A wiki page describing hostile wife phenomenon and summarizing what has been said about it. There are quite a few articles out there about this, but no summary as far as I can tell.

title: Inadequate equilibria
body: A wiki page summarizing the concept and giving a list of examples.

title: Robin Hanson summary
body:
A summary of Robin Hanson's "key ideas" like *homo hypocritus*, "X is not about Y", signaling, great filter, etc., would be nice. This would allow people to "catch up" on his thinking without having to spend a ton of time reading through poorly organized blog posts. Each of these might also need pages on the LessWrong Wiki, but that's a separate task.

[_The Elephant in the Brain_](http://elephantinthebrain.com/) now gives nice overviews of some of these ideas.

title: Timeline of Eliezer Yudkowsky publications
body:
See [Timeline of Carl Shulman publications](https://timelines.issarice.com/wiki/Timeline_of_Carl_Shulman_publications) and [Timeline of Wei Dai publications](https://timelines.issarice.com/wiki/Timeline_of_Wei_Dai_publications) for similar timelines that could be used as a model.

Eliezer has a lot of blog posts so it might be necessary to use some filtering criteria.

title: Some sort of program to check for arbitrary web page updates
body: There is [urlwatch](https://github.com/thp/urlwatch), which seems fine, but I would like the diff in the form of an RSS or Atom feed so that I can look over the updates in the same way I look over new blog post updates. A hack can probably be created fairly easily.

title: Rationality blogroll graph
body:
A graph showing which rationality community blogs have which blogs in their blogroll. To see if any patterns in e.g. subcommunities can be observed, and to uncover potentially interesting blogs.

The code can go on GitHub while a writeup could be posted to LW.

title: Research some trends in font usage
body: For instance, both Lato and Merriweather have become very popular in recent years. It seems like Minion Pro has supplanted Times New Roman as the new "boring default font". Default fonts for MS Word etc. have changed as well.

title: Improve timeline of online dating services
body:
Improve [Timeline of online dating services](https://timelines.issarice.com/wiki/Timeline_of_online_dating_services).

For example add info from [this piece](https://www.huffingtonpost.com/susie-lee/timeline-online-dating-fr_b_9228040.html). I also have a private discussion about more columns to add to the timeline (so find that before starting on this).

title: Improve pdftextfmt
body:
Improve [pdftextfmt](https://github.com/riceissa/pdftextfmt) to handle more PDF madness.

It's already fine for simple linebreaks and hyphens, but "word breaks" need to be handled manually (i.e. when there's a space within a word that's not supposed to be there). MuPDF also inserts strange lines containing just the character "f". Ligatures also often mess up the output.

title: Start a consciousness wiki
body:
A wiki systematically exploring issues related to consciousness. See more ideas [here](https://github.com/riceissa/issarice.com/tree/master/external/consciousness.issarice.com). The wiki can have an altruism/crucial considerations bent like [Luke Muehlhauser's moral patienthood report](https://www.openphilanthropy.org/2017-report-consciousness-and-moral-patienthood "Luke Muehlhauser. “2017 Report on Consciousness and Moral Patienthood”. Open Philanthropy Project. August 5, 2017. Retrieved November 20, 2017."). It can also apply the ideas to e.g. cryonics.

Specific article ideas will be added in separate issues.

title: Improve staycation page
body:
Improve [Staycation § Benefits](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Staycation#Benefits).

Some benefits can be framed as ways to avoid the downsides of international travel (jet lag, illness, and so on). I think Bryan Caplan discusses staycation in his kids book.

title: Timeline of web analytics
body: There is a stub for this [here](https://timelines.issarice.com/wiki/Timeline_of_web_analytics).

title: List of mysterious answers to mysterious questions
body: I think one reason I like the {Yudkowsky, Tomasik, Drescher, Dennett} approach to dealing with philosophy is that they treat all of the "big questions" or "mysterious questions" at once, rather than just treating one thing in isolation. But it seems like Drescher doesn't talk much about the problem of personal identity, and Yudkowsky's blog posts only pose it as a *question* (about the anthropic trilemma) rather than as an answer. I think having these all in one table would be nice, since I am tabulating a bunch these days. The columns could be "mysterious question", "mysterious answer", "resolution/dissolved answer".

title: Guide to working on wiki-like pages with Vim
body: I've developed some ideas about how to work on wiki-like pages in Vim, which is distinct from working on related program source code. Some useful options for this are `'isfname'`, `'includeexpr'`, and `'suffixesadd'`. Setting these to good values will allow for traveling between related pages on the wiki more easily. As a case study, MediaWiki could be used. Also see the [wikilink script](https://github.com/riceissa/contentcreation/blob/master/wikilink.vim) I use on one wiki.

title: Timeline of felicifia
body: I think quite a few EAs came from felicifia-related online presence, including Brian Tomasik, Pablo Stafforini, Ryan Carey, and Peter Hurford. Carl Shulman also has an account on the forums. It would be interesting to document its rise and decline.

title: Table on multiverses/Big World theories
body: Rows could be the multiverses: many worlds interpretation, modal realism, etc. See [Tegmark's classification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multiverse#Max_Tegmark.27s_four_levels) for example. The columns could be things like "how big?", "implications for altruism", "proponents".

title: Naturalism table
body: A table summarizing naturalistic worldviews. The columns can be "author", "view on consciousness", "view on free will", "view on time", etc. In other words, the "[mysterious questions](http://lesswrong.com/lw/iu/mysterious_answers_to_mysterious_questions/ "Eliezer Yudkowsky. “Mysterious Answers to Mysterious Questions”. LessWrong. August 25, 2007. Retrieved November 20, 2017.")". The authors that I would like to be covered are Yudkowsky, Tomasik, Gary Drescher, and Dennett. The cells of the table can contain the works by the author that discusses the views.

title: Pandoc scripting guide
body: A guide to scripting with Pandoc. Probably with Lua filters now that Pandoc 2.0 is out. It would be good to cover common frustrations like how to debug your filter, some common real-life filters, and so on.

title: Backpropagation explanation
body: I'm not satisfied by any of the explanations I have seen of backpropagation, and I want to see if I can do better.
